The Arab region's models achieve a $R^2_{adj}$ of 59.61\% for mobile cell subscriptions which indicates the models, on a whole sufficiently explain the variation of the predicted variables adjusted for the number of predictors in each model. The Cramer-Von Mises test found no variables' models that significantly satisfied the assumption of normally distributed residuals. On the other hand, mobile cell subscriptions and trade (\% of GDP) regression models produced insignificant Breusch-Pagan tests for constant variance where the null hypothesis was that the variance of the model's residuals is constant. To learn how well each variable was explained in a given country, the residuals were broken down for each nation's defined linear regression models. Within the Arab region, the variables, population density and trade(\% of GDP) were the two with the highest residuals or least well defined. Based on the Cramer-Von Mises statistic, they both scored the highest of the variables of interest for the least homoscedastic variance. Morocco and Syria each had the highest, abnormally large residuals within population density and trade (\% of GDP) respectively, and the Untied Arab Emirates had large residuals for both of these variables of interest.  The studentized residuals, used to identify outliers, found there to be outliers within four variables models: percent border conflict, trade (\% of GDP), population density, and fertility rate. There was some overlap with the larger residuals and those studentized residuals greater than three which is the threshold for an outlier (CITE Linear reg and forecasting book). Syria contained outlier residuals in percent border conflict and trade (\% of GDP) while Tunisia included an instance of abnormal studentized residual in its model of percent border conflict. The United Arab Emirate's population density linear regression predicted an outlier within its studentized residuals. Yemen's fertility rate model was the only other instance of a studentized residual greater than three. It is difficult to attribute these poor regression fits to any direct conflict trends as they along with other countries all had high likelihoods to enter conflict when the alternative futures were generated based on each variables of interests regressed on each other. 

In Table \@ref(tab:modeladequacy), the South East Asia region's regression models are evaluated on model performance and ability to maintain the assumptions of normally distributed variance with constant variance. The models or each variable of interest achieved at worst, a $R^2_{adj}$ of 65.88\% for the freshwater per capita. Of the Cramer-Von Mises tests' results, only two variables, population growth and average border conflict didn't violate the linear regression assumption that the model's residuals followed a normal distribution. The Breusch-Pagan test found no models of the South East Asia countries' variables of interest to have significantly constant variance of their errors. Taking a closer look at the each individual model's residuals by country, various variables performed especially poor for a few nations. Based on the ranges of each models' residuals, GDP per capita stands out as disproportionately having the largest residuals compared to the other variables of interests' models. It is difficult to tell with the more variables of interest for this region which specific countries contain poorly performing models, so the studentized residuals were calculated to in a way identify outlying values to indicated poor fits. Table \@ref(tab:weakSEmodels) identifies each of the variables models that contained an instance of a studentized residual greater than three and the coordinating country.

Both of these nations, despite being poorly explained by the models for two variables each, had different conflict trends in the alternative futures driven by unrestricted variable regression models. Singapore experienced an average percentage increase in all three conflict measurements, but Timor-Leste had similar conflict rates of transitions and likelihoods as historically observed. Due to this difference in conflict behavior between two countries that were seemingly poor fits by the most number of variables' models, this research cannot clearly attribute any conflict tendencies to countries that are notably undefined by the South East East Asia's variables of interest. 

## Future Alternative Models' Results and Evaluation

The regional, generic imputation style future alternative model was first run with only operational boundaries constraining the values of each variable of interest. The data's relationships and injected noise was able to determine the directions of each nation's future conflict transitions. To evaluate the model's statistically possibility three metrics were calculated for each repetition and averaged to understand the differences between future conflict timelines and the observed historic data for a nation as well as compare individual alternative futures. Each evaluation metric was calculated for the past ten years of observed data and future sixteen years of projected conflicts status. The rates of transitions were found over each past or future time period by counting the times a nation transitioned conflict status divided by the number of years in that period. For example, if a nation remained in conflict for the entirety of the projected future years then it would have transitioned zero times over sixteen years. Its rate of transitions for that nation's single future would be zero ($\frac{0}{16}$). The rates of transitions give insight into how closely or off the future alternatives are from the historic rates of conflict beginnings and stoppages in a specific nation. The conflict likelihood was calculated similarly but just by counting the number of years in conflict divided by the total years in that period of time. By finding the likelihood of each nation's alternative future, comparing the models' conflict likelihoods provides the possibility of that future alternative. Expanding on this idea, the most recent conflict likelihoods were calculated for the three most recent years of observed data and the first three future projected conflict statuses. Comparing the most recent conflict likelihood gives insight into the more recent similarities and differences that future alternatives predict versus reality. 

The Arab region in the past ten years has experienced 98 violent conflicts across seventeen countries: Algeria,	Bahrain, Egypt, Iraq,	Jordan,	Kuwait,	Lebanon, Libya, Morocco,	Oman,	Qatar,	Saudi Arabia,	Syria,	Tunisia,	United Arab Emirates,	West Bank, and	Yemen. The generic imputation driven forecasting model projected country conflict from 2015 to 2030. The model repeatedly projected future conflict five times to create five individual alternative futures for each country. The average predicted country conflicts across all five futures was 134.2 violent conflicts for the first ten years of future data. The associated minimum and maximum conflicts for a single future's total ten year conflicts were 125 and 145 respectively. Even on the lower end of projected future conflicts, there appears to be a larger estimates of conflicts that the data driven model predicts for the Arab region.

The average percentage changes for the three future alternative evaluation measures were the rate of transitions increased 15.123\% across all the countries and replications with a standard deviation of 70.591. The conflict likelihood increased an average of 82.716\% with a 172.506 standard deviation from the past ten years of country conflict likelihoods. The most recent (three year) conflict likelihood only decreased by 7.451\% with a standard deviation of 43.197. It seems like the closer projected future conflicts didn't deviate too far from the observed recent conflict realities, but the further away the futures were from the observed historical data, the larger the conflict likelihoods and rates of transitions became with wider bounds as well. This is partially the difficult with making predictions on projected future data. There is no guarantee the future will or should look like the past. 

The South East Asia regional conflict transition prediction model was applied to the generically imputation style forecasted data set. In the past ten years, the South East Asia region has experienced 136 violent conflicts throughout its 28 nations. With the developed alternative futures from letting the data's relationships dictate their own trends over time for five replications, an average of 97.2 violent conflicts were predicted for the first ten years of projected future conflict statuses. There was a minimum of 91 and maximum of 103 violent conflicts predicted by an individual alternate future replication, and interestingly, the same method applied to build a model in a different region outputted a different trend of overall decade conflict trend towards peace.

The model compared to the original ten years of observed data in the region on average across all countries and repetitions predicted a 104.61\% increase in the rate of transitions with a standard deviation of 121.941. The conflict likelihood for the future of the region only increased by 18.989\% with a standard deviation of 103.105. The most recent conflict likelihood comparison saw a decrease of 38.095\% with an associated standard deviation of 49.546. The South East Asia region overall saw the smallest average percentage change in historic conflict likelihood and was the least close to historic rates of transitions. Although the two regions are significantly different, they both predicted increased average percentage of changes in rate of transitions and conflict likelihood but on average predicted smaller likelihoods of more recent conflict. Both of these results based on the data driven alternative futures models are used as the base line of comparison for the regional questions analyzed in sections 4.2 and 4.3.

## Arab Nations' Regional Scenarios

The three regional scenarios were tested using modified versions of the purely data driven future alternative model. With the previously mentioned scripted behavior of the percentage of border conflicts of a given nation, the first regional scenario was tested to understand the regional impact of peaceful bordering nations. Despite the logical rational that peace besets peace, the results of this regional scenario were an overwhelming majority of countries entering conflict and staying in conflict for the duration of the future sixteen years. The peaceful borders' future alternatives, averaged across all five replications forecasted 184.6 yearly instances of violent conflicts in countries over the first ten future years. This was over double of the 98 observed instances of countries in violent conflict for the most recent ten years. The future conflicts with enacted peaceful bordering nations were about 50 conflicts more than the original data driven future conflict predicted. Looking closer into each individual country, only two countries across all five repetitions experience a year not in a state of conflict. Oman, Qatar, and United Arab Emirates entered states of non conflict only within the first three years of future data, and all other countries' conflict statuses were in conflict. The noticeable variable trends associated with all of the repeated states of conflict despite supposed peaceful bordering nations were low fertility rates, high population densities, and high mobile cell subscribers. Conflict transitions were influenced only when moderate levels of population density, fertility rate, trade (\% of GDP), and mobile cell subscribers existed. The peace in bordering countries does not appear to bring peace to the Arab nations themselves. Interestingly enough, the peaceful bordering nations lead the alternative futures to be have different average percentage of change from the observed historical data in the Arab region than the data driven original alternative future model. The peaceful border nations scenario had a negative average 57.243\% change of the rate of transitions, a 118.676\% increase in conflict likelihoods, and the more recent conflict transitions increase by 18.824\%. Compared to the purely data driven model, preset peaceful regional predicted greater average percentage changes in each of the three statistics. For the most part, increased peace in bordering Arab countries generated alternative futures of increased violent conflicts and minimal conflict transitions out of conflict. 

The second scenario of complete regional democratic governance show in an improved the overall Arab regional conflict environment. There were an average of 130.2 yearly instances of nation's being a state of conflict over the first ten years of projected data. This was a slightly smaller estimate than the data driven model, but the influence of democracies was still higher than the total number of conflicts in the most recent ten years of observed data. However, the all democratic governments average conflicts produced was a smaller standard deviation than the original data driven model indicating a smaller range of ten year conflict estimates. Oman, Qatar, Bahrain, Kuwait, Lebanon, and Morocco all experienced alternative futures completely in conflict with no transitions out of conflict. The years with continued violent conflicts and no transitions out of conflict were explained by high mobile cell subscribers, high population density, high percent of bordering conflicts, low fertility rates, and low trade (\% of GDP). It appeared that there was no significant impact that prescribed democracies had on the overall conflicts within a region. This research's three conflict measures had similar average percentage changes as the original imputed style forecasting method: increased rates of transitions, conflict likelihoods, and more recent conflict likelihoods. The only statistics' averages and standard deviations that didn't increase from the dictated democratic regimes were the recent, three year conflict likelihoods which had only an average percentage decrease of 3.529\% and standard deviation 46.554. The imposed state of democracy only improved the model's ability to predict conflict likelihoods more closely to the regions previous three years of conflict likelihoods across all seventeen country. Oman, Lebanon, and Morocco all saw no percentage change across all five repetitions from the historic conflict transitions. This appears that with the influenced democracies, the model produced recent (three year) conflict transitions identical to the recent previous observed conflict transitions when a given nations spent more years in a state of conflict. The countries that experienced the largest differences from the historic conflict behaviors in transitions and rates of transitions were Kuwait, Libya, and Oman. Two of these countries, not surprisingly received repeated high occurrences of conflict prediction during at least one repetition and reassured the model's tendency and impact of democracies like the original data driven model to predict statuses of conflict over not in conflict within the Arab region.

The third regional scenario simulated the reduction of trade as a percentage of GDP for each country in the Arab region. Future trade projects were set to the minimum historic trade levels within the Arab region to force each country to trade as infrequent as operationally realistic. Compared to the instances of conflict in the future ten years of data driven alternative futures, the decreased trade model predicted very similar violent conflict occurrences. There were 132.4 average conflicts in the first ten years of future data predictions which was only on average about two conflicts less than the original alternative future model. Bahrain, Libya, and Yemen were all predicted for all five repetitions to be in a state of conflict over the course of the entire forecast horizon. Of these three countries observed historic conflict trends, only Yemen had experienced a perfect historic conflict likelihood, meaning Yemen was in conflict the entire past ten years. Bahrain and Libya both have observed conflict likelihoods of 54.545\% and 36.364\% which indicates no clear relationship between the historic conflict likelihood and set decreased trade within each country then leading to consistent future years in conflict with no transitions. The preset decline in future trade (\% of GDP) generated very similar average percentage changes across all the regional countries' rates of transitions, conflict likelihoods, and recent (three year) conflict likelihoods. All of the average percentage changes' directions were the same as the original Arab data driven alternative futures while having higher differences between the rates of transitions and recent conflict likelihoods than the original model's rates. Only the overall forecast conflict likelihoods changed a few average percentage points from the historic conflict likelihood than the original model. This is likely due to the decline in trade predicting a few less conflicts and historically the Arab region has lower conflict occurrences and likelihoods than any alternative futures developed. Despite a marginally less conflict averages, there weren't any identifiable differences that closed trade had on the region's original data relationship driven conflict statuses and transitions.

## South East Asia's Regional Scenarios

The three regional scenarios aimed to test for the same three possible political and economic realities on the variables of interest in the South East Asia region. Peaceful bordering nations were fixed for the future data projections in order to see if peace would be likely to inspire more peace within a region. The binary border conflict and average bordering country conflict variables were hard coded to not allow any bordering nation exceed a HIIK score of three which means no violent conflicts would surround a given nation during the sixteen years of projected data. The peaceful border scenario predicted an average of 113.2 violent conflicts in South East Asia region's first ten forecasted years of data. Of the five repetitions, there was a high estimate of 124 total conflicts and low of 108. These summary statistics were all shifted towards larger averages of conflicts versus the free ranging original forecasted conflict predictions, but compared to the total, 136 violent conflicts in the past ten years of observed data, peaceful borders still estimated less future conflicts would arise in the next decade. The data, with its own relationships seems to already predict future conflicts trending downwards exclusive of peace abutting the region. Between the rates of transitions, conflict likelihoods, and recent conflict likelihoods, the first scenario didn't change any of positive or negative average percentage changes found by the original forecasting technique. The first scenario predicted less similar rates of transitions and conflict likelihoods to the original, historic ten years of observed data. Only the most recent, three years data conflict likelihoods were more similar to the original data's most recent conflict likelihoods than the novel imputation style alternative futures by about 20\%. This means that in the short term, when peace surrounds a South East Asian nation, its conflict likelihoods are more similar to recent historic conflict likelihoods, but then the further into the future those conflict likelihood's become more different. Kiribati and Mongolia were the nation's with the highest conflict likelihoods, but even these two nations had less than 0.5 likelihoods of conflict which compared to the Arab region, indicates that South East Asia's conflicts are trending downward. China, surrounded by peace, had small average conflict likelihood and future rate of transitions, but it scored a maximum of conflict likelihood of 0.5 meaning that in one alternate future China still has a higher likelihood of conflict in the region. The main takeaway is that with implemented peaceful borders, countries conflict statuses are less likely to change in the short term and still estimate less conflicts for the next ten years.  

The second scenario aimed to understand how set democratic governments would shift the conflict environment of the region. The regime type for each nation was set to democratic for the future years and their freedom scores restricted to not be lower than that of any observed democratic nation's in the region. The prescribed democracies still a downward ten year shift downwards of total conflicts compared to the historic count. Across all repetitions, an average of 133.2 instances of nation's in states of conflict were estimated which is less than the historic 136 records. This is a higher prediction than the original data driven forecasted method meaning with democracies in place, nation's conflicts are still going down but less than if the future alternatives were just driven by current data relationships. In the short term, like the previous regional scenario, the influence of democracies predicted more similar  conflict likelihoods to the historic data in the first three years than the original data driven model. After the first three years, the democratic scenario saw nearly double the average percentage changes in conflict likelihood and around a 35\% increase in nation's rates of transitions. China, North Korea, Kiribati, and Laos all had the highest average likelihoods of conflict which was interesting since except for Kiribati, none of these nations were previously governed by democracies or had freedom scores above the democratic nation's lower limit. It is possible that the influence of a regime change disrupted these nations more than brought about peace for them. The higher average rates of transitions were another possible outcome of the disruptive nature that implementing democracies in a region historically more autocratic. With the shift towards democracy, the region still experienced a lower conflicts in the ten years of alternative futures. 

The third regional scenario imitated the impact that huge declines in trade as a percentage of GDP would have on the South East Asia region of the world. Trade (\% of GDP) was limited to the lowest, historical trade levels ever practiced in the region to see the resulting conflicts trends. With a serious downturn in trade, the region experienced an average, estimated 139.8 total conflicts in the first ten years into the future. This was the first scenario to predict conflict to rise in the region compared to the 136 instances of violent conflict observed in the past ten years. It is expected that over the course of ten years, tensions in the region and countries conflicts would rise if nations seized to trade with one another. Compared to the alternative futures produced from unrestricted data relationships, the decline in trade resulted in higher average percentage changes of rates of transitions and conflict likelihoods from the past ten years of conflicts. Nations are transitioning in and out of conflict more and have a higher chance of being in conflict when their trade halts to a near stop. Only in the short term (three years) does the scenario actually yield conflict likelihoods about 30\% more similar to the actual data than the original alternative futures. This could be attributed to the impacts of changes in trade having a delayed effect on a nation's conflict status. Nations could possibly behave similarly for a few years before the decreased trade would lead them into conflicts. Bhutan, North Korea, Laos, and the Philippines were the nations with the highest average likelihoods of conflict in the alternative futures with closed off trade. Bhutan historically had spent over fifty percent of their GDP on trade which makes sense that their conflict likelihood shot up. North Korea, Laos, and the Philippines trade remained between thirty and forty five percent over the past decade making them possibly hurt by limited trade too. It was hard to determine an exact cause for the highest conflict likelihoods. All of the five nations that observed no status of conflicts in the past five years each entered at least one state of conflict across each repeated sixteen years of alternative conflicts. That could be due to the model's propensity to predict conflict over non conflict or the actual negative effects of nearly closing off trade in the region. 

# Conclusions

## Overall Conclusions

This study developed a methodology to impute open source data previously found to be influential for country conflict prediction in two regional groupings of countries and found the multiple alternative futures based on an explanatory forecasting approach. Individual linear regression models were built and evaluated for each of the variables of interest in each of the Arab and South East Asia regions. In each region, sixteen years of future data was projected and iteratively predicted upon to find the conflict transitions of every nation. Three regional scenarios were posed to understand shifts in nations' behaviors impact on the futures' conflict statuses. The results of the study led to several conclusions which are summarized in answering the original research questions.

**Question 1: How should the data set utilized in the Neumann study be imputed?**

Utilizing and testing the MICE package in R on the data yielded interesting results. The main tests used to compare the multiple imputed data sets by each MICE algorithm were investigating how closely the data followed the distribution of observed data. The Polity IV variable's missing observations were filled with knowledge provided by the regime type of a country. The MICE algorithm was applied to each region individually with all of the possible variables because of the assumed similarities between countries and all variable relationships within the a given region informing the imputed values. Five data sets of imputed values were generated for each of the five MICE algorithms. Using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov and non-parametric, 2-sample Anderson-Darling tests in addition to diagnostic plots decided the individual MICE algorithms for each variable containing missingness. It seemed that generally variables containing smaller levels of missingness were imputed using predictive mean matching while the variables with higher percentages of missingness tended to be imputed using either classification and regression trees or random forests MICE algorithm. Few variables were close to following a normal distribution so this form of MICE algorithm wasn't the option that imputed values closest to the observed distribution. Multiple imputations by chained equations generated showed to be a useful method of imputation for a data set with many variables with varying levels of missingness.

**Question 2: How can this research develop regression models for each variable of interest in a given region?**

Stepwise regression was the main technique used to develop parsimonious models for each region's individual variables of interest. Interaction terms were tentatively applied to better define a variable's relationship while avoiding overfitting and creating overly complicated models. All of the models within the Arab region included interaction terms while not every one of the South East Asia's models benefited from involving variable interactions. The $R^2_{adj}$ was the main metric used to evaluate the reduced regression models, and between both regions the $R^2_{adj}$ achieved were acceptable. The lowest $R^2_{adj}$'s between both regions' models was 59.61\%. The assumptions of linear regression were violated by a majority of the models in both regions. None of the five models in the Arab region satisfied the assumption of normally distributed residuals while only two of the eight models in the South East Asia region fulfilled it. The assumption of constant variance of a model's residuals was only met by two of the five Arab regional models, but none of the South East Asia variables' models maintained homoscedasticity. Multiple transformations were tested and applied depending their impact to a model's $R^2_{adj}$ and assumptions of linear regression. This research relaxes the assumptions of linear regression in order to proceed with explaining each variable of interest based on others in the region and predicting point estimates for alternative future develop. Outlier analysis based on studentized residuals found a few countries in each region that were poorly fit by certain variable's models, but these countries' future alternatives of conflict behavior didn't stand out among the rest of countries which were acceptably explained by the variables' models.

**Question 3: What insights, nations susceptible or impervious to conflict transitions are identified by the generated regional conflict future alternatives?**

In the Arab region, the data alternative futures driven by the relationships defined by the data predicted an overall ten year increase in conflicts compared to the observed past ten years of data. On average the future alternatives subject to no regional scenarios predicted 134.2 conflicts to arise in the next ten years opposed to 98 instances of conflict observed across the Arab region's nations. Conflict in the region was overall predicted to rise, and Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, and Tunisia were the four nations of the sixteen in the region that had higher likelihood of conflict than the five repetition average of regional conflict likelihood percentage change (82.716\%) making them the nations with conflict behavior least like their past. The only measure that the purely data driven future alternatives didn't predict would have an average percentage increase across the region was there was a small predicted average percentage decrease (7.451\%) of the most recent three years of conflict likelihoods compared to the observed most recent conflict likelihoods. The Arab region in the short term was less likely to be in conflict but in the long term the region saw an 82.716\% average increase in the likelihood of conflict. 

The South East Asia region experienced different conflict trends than the Arab region's general rise in instances of violent conflict. The alternative futures driven by unrestricted relationships of the variables of interest predicted that across all countries and repetitions there would be 97.2 conflicts in the next ten years. This is a serious downturn from the past ten years of observed data's 136 conflicts in the region. Neither region's ten year future conflict estimates had standard deviations greater than eight meaning they're convincingly different than the past total conflict counts. Despite having a small average percentage change in conflict likelihood (18.989\%), the alarming average percentage increase of likelihood of conflict that were greater than a 100\% increase occurred Bhutan, Samoa, and the Solomon Islands. The average rates of transitions in the region rose by 103.061\% meaning nations are transitioning conflict statuses much more often than historically on top of the general decrease of conflicts.

**Question 4: How robust are the future alternatives of conflict transitions to the what-if analysis scenarios tested for each region?**

The three scenarios generally tested on relevant variables of interest to each region were the impact of peaceful neighboring nations, democratic regime type, and a decline in trade (\% of GDP). The Arab region's average conflicts over the next ten years increased immensely compared to the ten years of total conflicts observed and even the free data driven alternative futures' estimate. With peaceful bordering countries, the region's conflicts over a ten year period nearly doubled which still indicates a rise in conflicts but at an expedited rate. The impact of democracy spreading through the region didn't have a real impact on the future conflict predictions compared to the 134.2 conflicts forecasted by the originally imputed alternative future model. Democracy slightly lowered the ten year average conflict future estimate to 130.8 but still predicted a stark rise in total conflicts from the historic record of 98 conflicts. The decline in trade (\% of GDP) in the Arab region's nations had little impact again on the region's average conflicts. The scenario produced 132.4 conflicts to occur in the next ten years which is higher than history showed but similar to the original alternative futures approximate. In general, the Arab region's future ten year's of conflict wasn't too sensitive to the regional scenarios besides peaceful bordering nations, but the region's conflicts were still predicted to increase by a minimum of about thirty violent conflicts. 

The South East Asia region was slightly more responsive to the preset changes to bordering nation, government, and trade. For each scenario, the region experienced an average increase in conflict occurrences over ten years compared to the original alternative futures algorithm's estimate. The peaceful bordering nations produced a future ten year average of 113.2 conflicts which was still a decrease from the 136 historically observed 136 conflicts observed in the past ten years. The influence of set democracy caused 133.2 conflicts on average over the future ten years while the decline in trade produced the highest future total conflicts over ten years. The near zero trade (\% of GDP) scenario estimated 139.8 average conflicts over the next ten years which was slightly higher than the historic ten years of conflict. All of the regional scenarios resulted in smaller average percentage changes from the historic data in the most recent, three years of conflict likelihoods when compared to the original future alternatives recent conflict likelihoods. The regional scenarios initially were more similar to history, but over the course of the forecast horizon, the regional scenarios generated higher rates of conflict transitions and likelihoods of conflict compared to both the historic data and original future alternatives. The South East Asia region saw the greatest conflict increase when trade was restricted which made sense considering that compared to the Arab region, South East Asia's countries historically spent a higher average percentage of their GDP on trade so more conflict would ensue based on this change. The installation of democracies and surrounding peace predicted a rise in a country's conflict. South East Asia contains a variety of governments, so the future alternatives indicate possibly enforcing democracy wouldn't allow the region to become peaceful on such a scale as originally forecasted. The South East Asia region was largely predicted to decrease in conflict over the next ten years except if trade (\% of GDP) greatly declines across the region.

## Significance of Research

In Issac Asimov's science fiction novel, _Foundations_, a new branch of mathematics is able to predict the future, but only on a large scale. The premise of the book is that the characters analyze their galaxies alternative futures, calculate that they are likely doomed, and take necessary actions to ensure an alternative future that mitigates their society's destruction. The alternative futures inform the characters' decisions just as these results provide insight to a point. There is a finite power to calculating  possible futures and inherent uncertainty whether the future should look resemble the past. This research develops alternative sixteen year futures for two world regions based on past data from 2004-2014, encompassing 45 countries. These alternate futures provide some regional conflict trends for consideration by military strategists for future operations. The resulting conflict environments are meaningful, but with the ever changing data patterns and regional relationships, the resultant conflict transitions provide insight for sensible cogitation. The regional and global military policies have such an immense impact that more forecasting analyses and expert opinion must be considered to inform decision making. 

## Future Research

As part of continuing research, this study recommends multiple areas for deeper analytical insights in alternative futures generation of country conflict. The first area for continuing this research is to expand the variables considered for each region. The scale of this entire project could be expanded to all of the available data. This research only considered the variables identified as influential in the Neumann `r citep(BIB[key="neumann"])` model for two regions, but all of the variables available and Neumann's regions could be incorporated and analyzed. There is a greater chance of developing improved regression models when more explanatory variables are considered and less of a chance that the assumptions of linear regression will be violated. 

In addition to expanding the variables considered to explain each region, an alternative model reduction technique could be applied to find the parsimonious models that make up a region. Stepwise regression was the foremost model reduction method used in this study, but there are alternate techniques that could simplify a region's variables' relationships. Lasso regression is one technique which could be explored to explain each region differently and find alternative futures. Any improvements that can be made to the linear regression models used to define and project the underlying relationships between the data would generate more informative alternative futures. 

This research's imputed future alternatives generative method could still be developed upon in the same manner that univariate missing data imputation methods have been progressed. This research took an predicted point estimate plus noise approach to defining the yearly estimates of each variable, but Van Buuren `r citep(BIB[key="vanbuuren"])` identified two other univariate imputation methods that incorporate more uncertainty: Bayesian multiple imputation and bootstrap multiple imputation. Both of these methods take the prediction plus noise formulation one step further by adding on parameter uncertainty. Expanding the imputation theory behind the alternative futures may be a possible area of expansion that this research could perpetuate. Incorporating more uncertainty into the method or testing an alternate future generation technique would only enhance decision makers knowledge towards developing of strategic and operational plans.
